unnormalised: ## Understanding Heart Health: A Simple Guide
normalised: ## Understanding Heart Health: A Simple Guide

unnormalised: Heart disease, or what we docs often refer to as cardiovascular disease, is a major health concern in India. It's not just a problem for older folks; increasingly, we're seeing younger adults, even those in their 30s and 40s, develop heart-related issues. This blog post aims to provide a simple understanding of cardiology and how to maintain a healthy heart.
normalised: Heart disease, or what we docs often refer to as cardiovascular disease, is a major health concern in India. It's not just a problem for older folks; increasingly, we're seeing younger adults, even those in their thirties and forties, develop heart-related issues. This blog post aims to provide a simple understanding of cardiology and how to maintain a healthy heart.

unnormalised: First, let's understand what cardiology is all about. Cardiology is the branch of medicine dealing with the heart and blood vessels. Cardiologists like Dr. Rajesh Khanna at Max Hospital, Delhi, specialize in diagnosing and treating conditions like heart attacks (myocardial infarctions), heart failure, arrhythmias (irregular heartbeats), and congenital heart defects. Common procedures include ECGs (electrocardiograms), echocardiograms (often called "echo's"), and angiograms. A routine checkup might include a BP reading (blood pressure), which should ideally be around 120/80 mmHg.
normalised: First, let's understand what cardiology is all about. Cardiology is the branch of medicine dealing with the heart and blood vessels. Cardiologists like Doctor Rajesh Khanna at Max Hospital, Delhi, specialize in diagnosing and treating conditions like heart attacks (myocardial infarctions), heart failure, arrhythmias (irregular heartbeats), and congenital heart defects. Common procedures include E-C-G's (electrocardiograms), echocardiograms (often called "echo's"), and angiograms. A routine checkup might include a B-P reading (blood pressure), which should ideally be around one hundred and twenty divided by eighty M-M H-G.

unnormalised: One of the key risk factors for heart disease is high cholesterol. Your doctor might order a lipid profile blood test. If your LDL cholesterol is consistently above 130 mg/dL, lifestyle changes and possibly medication may be necessary. Another common risk factor is hypertension (high blood pressure). Keeping your weight in check (BMI below 25 kg/m2) and engaging in regular physical activity are crucial in maintaining healthy blood pressure levels.
normalised: One of the key risk factors for heart disease is high cholesterol. Your doctor might order a lipid profile blood test. If your L-D-L cholesterol is consistently above one hundred and thirty milligram divided by D-L, lifestyle changes and possibly medication may be necessary. Another common risk factor is hypertension (high blood pressure). Keeping your weight in check (B-M-I below twenty five kilogram divided by meter squared) and engaging in regular physical activity are crucial in maintaining healthy blood pressure levels.

unnormalised: Diet plays a huge role. Traditional Indian diets can be heavy on saturated fats and refined carbohydrates, which can contribute to plaque buildup in arteries. Try to incorporate more fruits, vegetables, and whole grains into your meals. Limit your intake of ghee, butter, and fried foods like samosas and pakoras. Consider consulting a registered dietitian for personalized dietary advice; a simple change such as using olive oil instead of vegetable oil in daily cooking can improve health parameters by 10-15 %.

unnormalised: Exercise is equally important. Aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic exercise per week, such as brisk walking, cycling, or swimming. Even a 30-minute walk most days of the week can make a significant difference. Yoga and meditation can also help reduce stress, which is another risk factor for heart disease. Remember to always consult your doc before beginning an intense exercise regime, esp. if you have had any cardio-vascular issues in the past.
normalised: Exercise is equally important. Aim for at least one hundred and fifty minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic exercise per week, such as brisk walking, cycling, or swimming. Even a thirty-minute walk most days of the week can make a significant difference. Yoga and meditation can also help reduce stress, which is another risk factor for heart disease. Remember to always consult your doc before beginning an intense exercise regime, especially if you have had any cardiovascular issues in the past.

unnormalised: Smoking is an absolute no-no. It damages blood vessels and increases the risk of heart attack and stroke. Quitting smoking is one of the best things you can do for your heart health, regardless of how long you've been smoking. Support groups and nicotine replacement therapy can be helpful in quitting smoking. Seek professional help, if needed. A person who has been smoking 10 cigs a day for the past 15 years can expect to see improvements within a year of quitting.

unnormalised: Finally, regular check-ups with your cardiologist are essential, especially if you have a family history of heart disease or any other risk factors. Early detection and treatment can significantly improve outcomes and prevent serious complications. Don't ignore symptoms like chest pain, shortness of breath, or palpitations. Remember, taking care of your heart is a lifelong commitment to a healthier you, so schedule that ECG at your local clinic for around Rs. 800-1000.
